General Syntax

On this page

Arithmetic Operators ​

Baseline Feature
Version: 0.1.2
Status: ✅ Implemented
Test: 00_base_feats/03_arithmetic_ops.vx

Overview ​

Arithmetic operators perform mathematical operations on numeric values. Vex supports standard arithmetic operations with proper precedence and associativity.

Binary Operators ​

Addition (+) ​

Adds two numeric values:

rust
let sum = 5 + 3;        // 8
let total = 100 + 42;   // 142

let x = 10;
let y = 20;
let result = x + y;     // 30

Type compatibility:

  • Integer + Integer → Integer
  • Float + Float → Float
  • Both operands must have same type (or compatible after widening)

Subtraction (-) ​

Subtracts second operand from first:

rust
let diff = 10 - 4;      // 6
let balance = 1000 - 250; // 750

let a = 50;
let b = 30;
let result = a - b;     // 20

Multiplication (*) ​

Multiplies two values:

rust
let product = 6 * 7;    // 42
let area = 10 * 20;     // 200

let width = 5;
let height = 8;
let size = width * height; // 40

Division (/) ​

Divides first operand by second:

rust
let quotient = 20 / 4;  // 5
let half = 10 / 2;      // 5

// Integer division truncates
let x = 7 / 2;          // 3 (not 3.5)

// Float division
let precise: f64 = 7.0 / 2.0;  // 3.5

Division by zero: Runtime panic ("Runtime Error: Division by zero") Overflow: Signed integer division overflow (MIN / -1) triggers runtime panic.

Modulo (%) ​

Remainder after division:

rust
let remainder = 17 % 5;  // 2
let odd_check = 9 % 2;   // 1

let even = 10 % 2;       // 0

Sign behavior:

rust
let a = 17 % 5;    // 2
let b = -17 % 5;   // -2 (result has sign of dividend)
let c = 17 % -5;   // 2

Unary Operators ​

Negation (-) ​

Negates a numeric value:

rust
let positive = 42;
let negative = -positive;  // -42

let x = -10;              // -10
let y = -(-5);            // 5 (double negation)

Type preservation:

rust
let a: i32 = -100;        // i32
let b: f64 = -3.14;       // f64

Plus (+) (Unary) ​

Identity operator (no-op):

rust
let x = +42;     // 42 (same as just 42)

Operator Precedence ​

From highest to lowest:

PrecedenceOperatorsAssociativity
1Unary -, +Right
2*, /, %Left
3+, -Left

Examples:

rust
let a = 2 + 3 * 4;      // 14 (not 20)
let b = (2 + 3) * 4;    // 20 (parentheses override)

let c = 10 - 5 - 2;     // 3 (left associative: (10-5)-2)
let d = 12 / 3 / 2;     // 2 (left associative: (12/3)/2)

let e = -5 + 3;         // -2 (unary - has higher precedence)

Type Compatibility ​

Arithmetic operations require operands of compatible types:

rust
// Same type - OK
let i1: i32 = 10;
let i2: i32 = 20;
let sum = i1 + i2;      // i32

// Different integer types - requires cast
let a: i32 = 10;
let b: i64 = 20;
// let bad = a + b;     // ERROR: type mismatch
let good = a as i64 + b; // OK: both i64

// Float arithmetic
let f1: f64 = 3.14;
let f2: f64 = 2.71;
let result = f1 + f2;   // f64

Overflow Behavior ​

Integer arithmetic may overflow (wrapping behavior):

rust
let max_i8: i8 = 127;
let overflow = max_i8 + 1;  // -128 (wraps around)

let max_u8: u8 = 255;
let wrap = max_u8 + 1;      // 0 (wraps around)

Note: No runtime overflow checks in current implementation. Future: checked arithmetic methods.

Compound Assignment ​

Combined arithmetic and assignment:

rust
let! x = 10;
x += 5;     // x = x + 5; (15)
x -= 3;     // x = x - 3; (12)
x *= 2;     // x = x * 2; (24)
x /= 4;     // x = x / 4; (6)
x %= 5;     // x = x % 5; (1)

Requires mutable variable:

rust
let y = 10;
// y += 5;  // ERROR: y is immutable

let! z = 10;
z += 5;     // OK: z is mutable

Implementation ​

AST: vex-ast/src/expressions.rs ​

rust
pub enum BinaryOp {
    Add,        // +
    Subtract,   // -
    Multiply,   // *
    Divide,     // /
    Modulo,     // %
    // ...
}

pub enum UnaryOp {
    Minus,      // -
    Plus,       // +
    // ...
}

pub enum Expression {
    Binary {
        span_id: Option<String>,
        left: Box<Expression>,
        op: BinaryOp,
        right: Box<Expression>,
    },
    Unary {
        span_id: Option<String>,
        op: UnaryOp,
        expr: Box<Expression>,
    },
    // ...
}

Codegen: vex-compiler/src/codegen_ast/expressions/operators.rs ​

rust
pub(crate) fn compile_binary_op(
    &mut self,
    left: &Expression,
    op: &BinaryOp,
    right: &Expression,
) -> Result<BasicValueEnum<'ctx>, String> {
    let left_val = self.compile_expression(left)?;
    let right_val = self.compile_expression(right)?;

    match op {
        BinaryOp::Add => {
            if left_val.is_int_value() {
                self.builder.build_int_add(
                    left_val.into_int_value(),
                    right_val.into_int_value(),
                    "addtmp"
                )
            } else {
                self.builder.build_float_add(
                    left_val.into_float_value(),
                    right_val.into_float_value(),
                    "addtmp"
                )
            }
        }
        BinaryOp::Subtract => { /* similar */ }
        BinaryOp::Multiply => { /* similar */ }
        BinaryOp::Divide => { /* similar */ }
        BinaryOp::Modulo => {
            // Integer remainder
            self.builder.build_int_signed_rem(
                left_val.into_int_value(),
                right_val.into_int_value(),
                "modtmp"
            )
        }
        _ => Err(format!("Unsupported operator: {:?}", op)),
    }
}

LLVM Instructions ​

OperatorInteger InstructionFloat Instruction
+addfadd
-subfsub
*mulfmul
/sdiv / udivfdiv
%srem / uremfrem

Examples from Test ​

From Specifications/Tests/00_base_feats/03_arithmetic_ops.vx:

rust
fn main(): i32 {
    // Addition
    let add_result = 5 + 3;
    assert(add_result == 8, "Addition");

    // Subtraction
    let sub_result = 10 - 4;
    assert(sub_result == 6, "Subtraction");

    // Multiplication
    let mul_result = 6 * 7;
    assert(mul_result == 42, "Multiplication");

    // Division
    let div_result = 20 / 4;
    assert(div_result == 5, "Division");

    // Modulo
    let mod_result = 17 % 5;
    assert(mod_result == 2, "Modulo");

    // Negative numbers
    let neg_result = -10;
    assert(neg_result == -10, "Negation");

    // Mixed operations
    let mixed = 2 + 3 * 4;
    assert(mixed == 14, "Operator precedence");

    let parens = (2 + 3) * 4;
    assert(parens == 20, "Parentheses");

    // Float arithmetic
    let float_add = 1.5 + 2.5;
    assert(float_add == 4.0, "Float addition");

    let float_mul = 2.0 * 3.5;
    assert(float_mul == 7.0, "Float multiplication");

    return 0;
}
